a-final-word-on-cyclic-groups.text: A final word on cyclic groups

pageProps.body:
Homomorphisms

I HOMO





morphisms

(Would totally buy a T-shirt with that on it, by the way.)

Homomorphisms

Yes, yes, everyone's heard the jokes: "local topologist orders a coffee and a donut, ends up biting the coffee mug" this, "local topologist wakes up, tries fitting their head through a fidget spinner for an hour, gets arrested for public nudity" that. But have you considered the fact that people with a single ear piercing are already homomorphic to a pretzel?

"Homomorphism" means "same shape": if two objects are homomorphic, they have the same underlying shape or structure - donuts and coffee mugs, each being characterized by only having a single hole. In very basic and blasphemously un-rigorous terms, we begin our definition with this notion in mind:

Definition (but not quite yet.) A homomorphism is a comparison - or, in slightly fancier math-speak, a map - from one thing to another that establishes how these two things have the same underlying structure.

The "things" in question could be any two objects that has ever existed, as long as they have identical underlying structures; and the map that establishes the homomorphism is simply any action that connects the two objects. A sphere and a coffee mug, by means of deformation; the integers to the rationals, by means of division; the frog to the handsome prince, by means of true love's kiss.

In our case, though, we are concerned with groups; and more specifically, we are concerned with preserving the structures of groups. So what does the structure of a group entail? (Based on the number of discord groups I've been in, I'd bet on unitary dictatorship.)

Consider the cyclic group of integers mod 3\text{mod }3mod 3: the set {0,1,2}\{0, 1, 2\}{0,1,2}, nothing more. The structure of this group is given by how the elements of the group interact with each other: 111 and 222 combine to form 000, 222 and 222 to form 111, and so on.

In other words, the elements themselves aren't important; what matters is the relationship between them. So the question to be asked is: if we replace 0,10, 10,1 and 222 with a,ba, ba,b and ccc respectively (and, it must be emphasized, in that order), do we still preserve the same set of relationships - that 1+2=01 +2 = 01+2=0 and so b+c=ab + c = ab+c=a, and everything else besides?

This leads us to our first proper definition of what a group homomorphism entails.

Definition. The elements of a group (G,⋅G,eG)(G, \cdot_G, e_G)(G,⋅G​,eG​) combine with each other through the binary operation ⋅G\cdot_G⋅G​: to see how a,b∈Ga, b \in Ga,b∈G interact, consider a⋅Gba \cdot_G ba⋅G​b. These combinations form what are called the underlying structure of GGG.

Suppose there exists another group (H,⋅H,eH)(H, \cdot_H, e_H)(H,⋅H​,eH​), with its own binary operation and identity element. Call HHH and GGG homomorphic if there is a map ϕ\phiϕ that takes any three elements g1,g2,g3∈Gg_1, g_2, g_3 \in Gg1​,g2​,g3​∈G to three elements h1,h2,h3∈Hh_1, h_2, h_3 \in Hh1​,h2​,h3​∈H and preserves the relationship between them: that is, if g1⋅Gg2=g3g_1 \cdot_G g_2 = g_3g1​⋅G​g2​=g3​, then h1⋅Hh2=h3h_1 \cdot_H h_2 = h_3h1​⋅H​h2​=h3​.

Slightly more elegantly: there is a function ϕ\phiϕ that takes every element in GGG to some element in HHH such that g1⋅Gg2=g3g_1 \cdot_G g_2 = g_3g1​⋅G​g2​=g3​ implies ϕ(g1)⋅Hϕ(g2)=ϕ(g3)\phi(g_1) \cdot_H \phi(g_2) = \phi(g_3)ϕ(g1​)⋅H​ϕ(g2​)=ϕ(g3​). Even more elegantly: "show me your true form!"

With the above description in hand, call ϕ\phiϕ the homomorphism that maps GGG to HHH.

Examples.

  1. ϕ(x)=x\phi(x) = xϕ(x)=x, x∈Gx \in Gx∈G is a homomorphism from GGG to GGG. (Cool.)
  2. ϕ(x)=x\phi(x) = xϕ(x)=x, x∈Hx \in Hx∈H is a homomorphism from HHH to GGG if H≤GH \leq GH≤G. (Cool.)
  3. As seen from the multiplication table above, ϕ(x)=ex2πin\phi(x) = e^{x\frac{2\pi i}{n}}ϕ(x)=exn2πi​ is a homomorphism from the cyclic group comprised of numbers mod n\text{mod }nmod n and the cyclic group of rotational symmetries of an nnn-gon.
  4. ϕ(x)=mxn\phi(x) = \frac{mx}{n}ϕ(x)=nmx​ is a homomorphism from the cyclic group mod n\text{mod }nmod n to the cyclic group mod m\text{mod }mmod m, if m=knm = knm=kn for some positive integer kkk.

The above definition of a homomorphism encompasses more than immediately meets the eye.

Lemma. Suppose that ϕ\phiϕ is a group homomorphism between groups (G,⋅G,eG)(G, \cdot_G, e_G)(G,⋅G​,eG​) and (H,⋅H,eH)(H, \cdot_H, e_H)(H,⋅H​,eH​), denoted ϕ:G→H\phi: G\to Hϕ:G→H. Then the following two group axioms are preserved between GGG and HHH:

  1. Identity: ϕ(eG)=eH\phi(e_G) = e_Hϕ(eG​)=eH​. The homomorphism ϕ\phiϕ must map the identity of GGG to the identity of HHH.
  2. Inverse: ϕ(g)−1=ϕ(g−1)\phi(g)^{-1} = \phi(g^{-1})ϕ(g)−1=ϕ(g−1) for g∈Gg \in Gg∈G, where the first inverse is taken with respect to ⋅H\cdot_H⋅H​ and the second with respect to ⋅G\cdot_G⋅G​. The homomorphism ϕ\phiϕ must map an inverse to the same inverse.

Proof.

  1. Identity. For all g∈Gg\in Gg∈G, we have ϕ(g)⋅Hϕ(eG)=ϕ(g⋅GeG)=ϕ(g)\phi(g) \cdot_H \phi(e_G) = \phi(g\cdot_G e_G) = \phi(g)ϕ(g)⋅H​ϕ(eG​)=ϕ(g⋅G​eG​)=ϕ(g) by definition of a homomorphism. As such, we write

    ϕ(g)⋅Hϕ(eG)=ϕ(g),∀g∈G\phi(g) \cdot_H \phi(e_G) = \phi(g), \forall g \in Gϕ(g)⋅H​ϕ(eG​)=ϕ(g),∀g∈G

    which leads to ϕ(eG)=eH\phi(e_G) = e_Hϕ(eG​)=eH​ by definition of the identity.

  2. Inverse. Consider

    ϕ(g⋅Gg−1)=ϕ(g)⋅Hϕ(g−1) by definition of ϕ=ϕ(eG) by g⋅Gg−1=eG=eH by the above\begin{aligned} \phi(g \cdot_G g^{-1}) &= \phi(g) \cdot_H \phi(g^{-1}) \text{ by definition of $\phi$} \\ &= \phi(e_G) \text{ by $g\cdot_G g^{-1} = e_G$} \\ &= e_H \text{ by the above} \\ \end{aligned}ϕ(g⋅G​g−1)​=ϕ(g)⋅H​ϕ(g−1) by definition of ϕ=ϕ(eG​) by g⋅G​g−1=eG​=eH​ by the above​

    leading to ϕ(g−1)=ϕ(g)−1\phi(g^{-1}) = \phi(g)^{-1}ϕ(g−1)=ϕ(g)−1 by definition of the inverse.

Isomorphisms

In the simplest terms, homomorphisms are structure-preserving maps from one group to another; but nowhere does it say that for two groups to be homomorphic, they have to be the same size or correspond exactly to one another. A homomorphism ϕ:G→H\phi: G \to Hϕ:G→H is a function with domain equal to the set of GGG by definition, but its codomain (range) need not be the entirety of HHH; a subset is enough. In visual terms, the structure of GGG is embedded within HHH.

If instead we required the two groups to have the exact same size, and for ϕ\phiϕ to have its codomain equal HHH - for there to be a one-to-one correspondence between GGG and HHH, we would have

Definition. Isomorphisms are a one-to-one correspondence between groups: if a homomorphism ϕ\phiϕ is an invertible (one-to-one) function which has GGG as its domain and HHH as its codomain, call ϕ\phiϕ an isomorphism and write G≅HG \cong HG≅H.

Isomorphisms map two groups to one another exactly: the groups must have the exact same size (due to invertible functions being one-to-one by nature), and if ggg is mapped to hhh by an isomorphism ϕ\phiϕ, then hhh is mapped to ggg by its inverse. Isomorphic groups reach the highest level of similarity between two groups without actually reaching equality: they have the same number of elements, and the relationships between these elements follow the same underlying structure. We also call the one-to-one mapping represented by ϕ\phiϕ a bijection.

Image and Kernel

Definition. Suppose that GGG is homomorphic to HHH via the homomorphism ϕ:G→H\phi: G \to Hϕ:G→H. Call the set represented by the codomain of ϕ\phiϕ

Im(ϕ)={ϕ(g) ∣ g∈G}\text{Im}(\phi) = \{\phi(g)\ |\ g \in G\}Im(ϕ)={ϕ(g) ∣ g∈G}

the image of ϕ\phiϕ; and the set represented by all elements of GGG that map to the identity of HHH

Ker(ϕ)={g∈G ∣ ϕ(g)=eH}\text{Ker}(\phi) = \{g \in G\ |\ \phi(g) = e_H\}Ker(ϕ)={g∈G ∣ ϕ(g)=eH​}

its kernel.

Proposition. The image of ϕ\phiϕ is a subgroup of HHH; the kernel of ϕ\phiϕ is a subgroup of GGG.

Proof.

By definition of the homomorphism ϕ\phiϕ and the above lemmas, ϕ(eG)=eH\phi(e_G) = e_Hϕ(eG​)=eH​, meaning that Im(ϕ)\text{Im}(\phi)Im(ϕ) is non-empty. As such, we can apply our second lemma for confirming the existence of a subgroup. Consider x,y∈Gx, y \in Gx,y∈G and ϕ(x),ϕ(y)∈H\phi(x), \phi(y) \in Hϕ(x),ϕ(y)∈H. We have

ϕ(x)⋅Hϕ(y)−1=ϕ(x)⋅Hϕ(y−1)=ϕ(x⋅Gy−1)∈H\phi(x) \cdot_H \phi(y)^{-1} = \phi(x) \cdot_H \phi(y^{-1}) = \phi(x \cdot_G y^{-1})\in Hϕ(x)⋅H​ϕ(y)−1=ϕ(x)⋅H​ϕ(y−1)=ϕ(x⋅G​y−1)∈H

making Im(H)\text{Im}(H)Im(H) a subgroup of HHH.

Similarly, for Ker(ϕ)\text{Ker}(\phi)Ker(ϕ) we know that eG∈Ker(ϕ)e_G \in \text{Ker}(\phi)eG​∈Ker(ϕ) from the above lemmas, making the kernel non-empty; supposing that x,y∈Ker(ϕ)x, y \in \text{Ker}(\phi)x,y∈Ker(ϕ), we have

ϕ(x⋅Gy−1)=ϕ(x)⋅Hϕ(y−1)=eH⋅H(eH)−1=eH\phi(x \cdot_G y^{-1}) = \phi(x) \cdot_H \phi(y^{-1}) = e_H \cdot_H (e_H)^{-1} = e_Hϕ(x⋅G​y−1)=ϕ(x)⋅H​ϕ(y−1)=eH​⋅H​(eH​)−1=eH​

and thus x⋅Gy−1∈Ker(ϕ)x \cdot_G y^{-1} \in \text{Ker}(\phi)x⋅G​y−1∈Ker(ϕ), confirming that the kernel is a subgroup.

The notions of an image and kernel give us a useful way of confirming whether a homomorphism is an isomorphism.

Theorem. let ϕ:G→H\phi: G \to Hϕ:G→H be a homomorphism from groups GGG to HHH. ϕ\phiϕ is an isomorphism if and only if Im(ϕ)=H\text{Im}(\phi) = HIm(ϕ)=H and Ker(ϕ)=eG\text{Ker}(\phi) = e_GKer(ϕ)=eG​.

Proof.

Let's tackle the forward statement first. Suppose that ϕ\phiϕ is an isomorphism; thus ϕ\phiϕ is invertible, yielding

h=ϕ(ϕ−1(h))h = \phi(\phi^{-1}(h))h=ϕ(ϕ−1(h))

for all h∈Hh \in Hh∈H; therefore the image of ϕ\phiϕ encompasses all of HHH. If an element g∈Gg\in Gg∈G satisfies ϕ(g)=eH\phi(g) = e_Hϕ(g)=eH​, then we have

ϕ−1(ϕ(g))=ϕ−1(eH)=eG\phi^{-1}(\phi(g)) = \phi^{-1}(e_H) = e_Gϕ−1(ϕ(g))=ϕ−1(eH​)=eG​

as we know that ϕ(eG)=eH\phi(e_G) = e_Hϕ(eG​)=eH​ by the isomorphism lemmas above. This provides the forward statement.

Conversely, let Im(ϕ)=H\text{Im}(\phi) = HIm(ϕ)=H and Ker(ϕ)=eG\text{Ker}(\phi) = e_GKer(ϕ)=eG​. If Im(ϕ)=H\text{Im}(\phi) = HIm(ϕ)=H, then every element h∈Hh \in Hh∈H can be written h=ϕ(gh)h = \phi(g_h)h=ϕ(gh​) for some g∈Gg \in Gg∈G. Now define a new function ψ\psiψ, such that

ψ(h)=gh,∀h∈H\psi(h) = g_h, \forall h \in Hψ(h)=gh​,∀h∈H

which satisfies ϕ(ψ(h))=h\phi(\psi(h)) = hϕ(ψ(h))=h by definition. To prove that ψ\psiψ is the inverse to ϕ\phiϕ, we must prove that it also satisfies ψ(ϕ(g))=g\psi(\phi(g)) = gψ(ϕ(g))=g for all g∈Gg \in Gg∈G. We have

ϕ(g−1⋅Gψ(ϕ(g)))=ϕ(g−1)⋅Hϕ(ψ(ϕ(g)))=ϕ(g)−1⋅Hϕ(g)=eH\phi(g^{-1}\cdot_G \psi(\phi(g))) = \phi(g^{-1}) \cdot_H \phi(\psi(\phi(g))) = \phi(g)^{-1} \cdot_H \phi(g) = e_Hϕ(g−1⋅G​ψ(ϕ(g)))=ϕ(g−1)⋅H​ϕ(ψ(ϕ(g)))=ϕ(g)−1⋅H​ϕ(g)=eH​

and as such g−1⋅Gψ(ϕ(g))=eGg^{-1} \cdot_G \psi(\phi(g)) = e_Gg−1⋅G​ψ(ϕ(g))=eG​ by the fact that Ker(ϕ)=eG\text{Ker}(\phi) = e_GKer(ϕ)=eG​, meaning that g=ψ(ϕ(g))g = \psi(\phi(g))g=ψ(ϕ(g)). This leads to ψ=ϕ−1\psi = \phi^{-1}ψ=ϕ−1, and thus to the fact that ϕ\phiϕ is invertible. □\square□

A final word on cyclic groups

All this fuss about homomorphisms and isomorphisms allows us to study cyclic groups more closely: more precisely, the fact that its basic structure - a certain action, or generator, combining with itself to create the entire group - also underlies many other groups, or subgroups of many other groups.

Theorem. All cyclic groups GGG are isomorphic to either the group CnC_nCn​ (the group of rotational symmetries of an nnn-gon) or the infinite-order cyclic group (Z,+,0)(\mathbb{Z}, +, 0)(Z,+,0).

Proof.

An isomorphism requires an invertible function ϕ\phiϕ that maps each element of GGG to a unique element in CnC_nCn​ (which has nnn elements). As outlined by the theorem, there are two possible cases: either GGG is isomorphic to a finite cyclic group, or to the infinite-order cyclic group Z\mathbb{Z}Z.

First consider the case that the group GGG is finite, with nnn elements including the identity; by definition of a cyclic group, suppose that GGG has generator aaa: G={a0,a1,...,an−1}G = \{a^0, a^1, ..., a^{n-1}\}G={a0,a1,...,an−1} with an=eGa^n = e_Gan=eG​. nnn is thus the smallest natural number kkk satisfying ak=eGa^k = e_Gak=eG​; by definition we also have a2n=a3n=...=eGa^{2n} = a^{3n} = ... = e_Ga2n=a3n=...=eG​. Construct the homomorphism ϕ:Cn→G\phi: C_n \to Gϕ:Cn​→G, with CnC_nCn​ containing the elements {ω0,ω1,...,ωn−1}\{\omega^0, \omega^1, ..., \omega^{n-1}\}{ω0,ω1,...,ωn−1} with ω=e2πin\omega = e^{\frac{2\pi i}{n}}ω=en2πi​, such that

ϕ(ωk)=ak\phi(\omega^k) = a^kϕ(ωk)=ak

for k=0,1,...,n−1k = 0, 1, ..., n-1k=0,1,...,n−1. This satisfies the basic condition for a homomorphism:

ϕ(ωm⋅Cωn)=ϕ(ωm+n)=am+n=am⋅Gan=ϕ(ωm)⋅Gϕ(ωn)\phi(\omega^{m} \cdot_C \omega^{n}) = \phi(\omega^{m+n}) = a^{m+n} = a^m \cdot_G a^n = \phi(\omega^m) \cdot_G \phi(\omega^n)ϕ(ωm⋅C​ωn)=ϕ(ωm+n)=am+n=am⋅G​an=ϕ(ωm)⋅G​ϕ(ωn)

Recall that for a homomorphism to be an isomorphism Cn→GC_{n} \to GCn​→G, two conditions are necessary and sufficient: first that the homomorphism ϕ\phiϕ has image equalling GGG, and second that ϕ\phiϕ has kernel eCn=ω0e_{C_n} = \omega^0eCn​​=ω0.

The first condition is satisfied by construction; ϕ(ωk)=ak\phi(\omega^k) = a^kϕ(ωk)=ak, and thus ϕ\phiϕ has an image encompassing all of GGG. Assume for the sake of contradiction that Ker(ϕ)≠{ω0}\text{Ker}(\phi) \neq \{\omega^0\}Ker(ϕ)={ω0}; then for some 0≤k≤n−10 \leq k \leq n-10≤k≤n−1, we have ϕ(ωk)=ak=eG\phi(\omega^{k}) = a^{k} = e_Gϕ(ωk)=ak=eG​ by construction of ϕ\phiϕ. As nnn is the smallest natural number kkk satisfying ak=eGa^k = e_Gak=eG​, this reaches a contradiction; thus ϕ\phiϕ is an isomorphism.

If GGG is instead infinite, consider the same homomorphism ϕ\phiϕ, now from (Z,+,0)(\mathbb{Z}, +, 0)(Z,+,0) to GGG instead:

ϕ(k)=ak\phi(k) = a^kϕ(k)=ak

for all k∈Zk \in \mathbb{Z}k∈Z. As above, this also satisfies the basic requirements for a homomorphism; the same argument involving Ker(ϕ)\text{Ker}(\phi)Ker(ϕ) also reaches a contradiction, leading to ϕ\phiϕ being an isomorphism. □\square□

Definition. For any group GGG and a group element g∈Gg \in Gg∈G, define the order of ggg, denoted ord(g)\text{ord}(g)ord(g), as the smallest number nnn satisfying gn=eGg^n = e_Ggn=eG​. If no such number exists, we say that ggg has infinite order: ord(g)=∞\text{ord}(g) = \inftyord(g)=∞.

The subset of GGG generated entirely by powers of ggg - {g0,g1,...,gn}\{g^0, g^1, ..., g^n\}{g0,g1,...,gn} - forms a cyclic subgroup of GGG that is isomorphic to CnC_nCn​.
